skill.name: ghe-checkpoint
skill.description:
POST a progress checkpoint to the CURRENTLY ACTIVE thread. Saves work state without changing phases. Requires an already-claimed in-progress thread.

USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User says "post a checkpoint" or "save my progress"
- User says "update the issue" or "record current state"
- User says "checkpoint" or "save checkpoint"
- User completed a milestone and wants to record it
- User encountered a blocker and wants to document it
- User is about to take a break and wants to save state
- Meaningful state change occurred during work

PRECONDITION: User must already have an active (claimed, in-progress) thread.

DO NOT USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User wants to SEE status (use ghe-status)
- User wants to START work on new issue (use ghe-claim)
- User wants to FINISH current phase and MOVE to next (use ghe-transition)
- User wants reports (use ghe-report)
- No active thread exists (must claim first)

EXAMPLES:
<example>
Context: User working on DEV wants to save progress
user: "Post a checkpoint"
assistant: "I'll use ghe-checkpoint to post your current progress to the active thread"
</example>
<example>
Context: User completed a milestone
user: "Save my progress, I finished the authentication module"
assistant: "I'll use ghe-checkpoint to record this milestone"
</example>
<example>
Context: User taking a break
user: "I need to stop for now, save my work"
assistant: "I'll use ghe-checkpoint to save your current state before you go"
</example>

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code. Operates by spawning thread manager agents to post to GitHub. No direct file system access, network calls, or command execution within the skill itself.

content.user_title: Save progress to GitHub issue thread
content.value_statement: Users need a way to record work progress without disrupting their current workflow phase. This skill allows saving checkpoints directly to the active GitHub issue thread, preserving context for future sessions and team visibility.
actual_capabilities: Find the currently active GitHub issue thread
Gather work state including tasks, files, and commits
Post formatted progress checkpoint to issue
Update SERENA memory bank with current state
limitations: Requires an already claimed and in-progress thread
Cannot be used when no active thread exists
Does not transition between phases (use ghe-transition instead)
Does not generate reports (use ghe-report instead)

best_practices: Post checkpoints at meaningful state changes, not just time intervals
Include specific details about completed tasks and blockers
Update checkpoint before taking breaks or ending sessions
Use consistent checkpoint format for easy tracking
anti_patterns: Using checkpoint instead of ghe-transition when ready to move phases
Posting checkpoints without meaningful progress to report
Skipping checkpoint before long breaks or session ends
Using checkpoint when no active thread exists

faq.question: Does this skill work without an active GitHub issue?
faq.answer: No. You must first claim an issue using ghe-claim skill before posting checkpoints.

faq.question: How long do checkpoint records persist?
faq.answer: Checkpoints persist in the GitHub issue thread indefinitely as part of the issue conversation.

faq.question: Can I use this with other GHE skills?
faq.answer: Yes. Works with ghe-status, ghe-transition, and ghe-report for complete workflow management.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: Checkpoints are posted directly to your GitHub issue. No third-party data collection occurs.

faq.question: What if checkpoint posting fails?
faq.answer: The skill reports failure and suggests troubleshooting steps. Check GitHub API access and issue state.

faq.question: How is this different from ghe-transition?
faq.answer: Checkpoint saves progress without changing phase. Transition completes the current phase and moves to the next.
